overview.short: Aggregatibacter species are fastidious, Gram-negative coccobacilli within the Pasteurellaceae family, commonly associated with oral flora and endocarditis.
overview.clinical_context: Members of the HACEK group; most frequently implicated in infective endocarditis and periodontal disease.

field_notes.Shape: Often described as coccobacilli microscopically; normalized here as Short Rods.
field_notes.Growth Requirements: Many species are fastidious and may require enriched media such as chocolate agar.

key_differentiators.notes: Aggregatibacter species are non-motile, helping distinguish them from some Haemophilus species.
Oxidase negativity helps rule out oxidase-positive Gram-negative cocci.
Poor growth on MacConkey Agar helps separate Aggregatibacter from enteric Gram-negative rods.

common_confusions.reason: Shared family (Pasteurellaceae) and similar fastidious growth requirements.
Both are HACEK organisms associated with endocarditis.

when_to_question_identification: Robust growth on MacConkey Agar argues against Aggregatibacter.
Oxidase positivity suggests Neisseria or Moraxella.
Strong lactose fermentation is inconsistent with Aggregatibacter.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Helps distinguish Aggregatibacter from Haemophilus species.
HACEK organisms often grow slowly and may require prolonged incubation.
Recommended due to fastidious growth and biochemical overlap.
